title: "Bad file descriptor" appending to file from command on Windows Git Bash
body:
The following code for appending the output of a `Command` to a file works as expected on Linux (Ubuntu 20.10), but not on Windows (11).

```rust
use std::{fs::OpenOptions, process::Command};

// The following example works on Linux, but not on Windows.
fn main() {
    let file = OpenOptions::new()
        .append(true) // Works if replaced by .write(true)
        .create(true)
        .open("output-file")
        .unwrap();

    let mut command = Command::new("echo");
    command.arg("test");
    command.stdout(file);

    command.spawn().unwrap().wait().unwrap();
}
```

The expected result is that the file `output-file` is created on the first execution and that each execution appends "test" to the same file. This works as intended on Linux.

On Windows, the same code fails with:
> echo: write error: Bad file descriptor

There are no errors when using `write(true)` rather than `append(true)` on Windows.

I have tried with other commands on Windows, but there seems to be no difference.

### Meta

